channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Latin America Shifts Left, Leaders Face a Bleak Reality.
item.description: All six of the region’s largest economies could soon be run by presidents elected on leftist platforms. Their challenge? Inflation, war in Europe and growing poverty at home.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Mitra Taj and John Bartlett
item.media:credit: Javier Torres/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Students taking part in an anti-government protest in June in Santiago.

item.title: Zelensky Urges Mass Evacuation; Grain Tycoon Killed in Bombardment
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky asked civilians to leave eastern Ukraine, where there is a near complete absence of electricity and gas supply. One of the country’s richest business leaders was among the dead on a night of heavy shelling in the city of Mykolaiv.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Nancy Pelosi Headed to Singapore, Silent on Taiwan
item.description: President Biden’s aides said she was expected to proceed with a plan to visit Taiwan, the prospect of which has jangled nerves in both Beijing and Washington.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she was eager for Congress to be part of President Biden’s Indo-Pacific strategy.

item.title: A Nigerian Street Vendor Is Beaten to Death in Italy as Witnesses Stand By
item.description: The killing, in a seaside town on the Adriatic, has shocked Italians because of its brutality and because of the indifference of those looking on.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Chiara Gabrielli/Associated Press
item.media:description: A memorial at the spot where Alika Ogorchukwu was killed in Civitanova Marche, Italy.

item.title: Prince Charles’s Charity Accepted Millions From Family of Osama bin Laden
item.description: Clarence House confirmed that the terrorist’s brothers donated money to the royal charity, but denied reports that the prince had personally brokered the deal or made the decision to accept it.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Matthew Horwood/Getty Images
item.media:description: Prince Charles previously admitted to personally accepting $3.1 million in cash from a Qatari billionaire, some of which was delivered in a suitcase.

item.title: Fidel Ramos, Philippine President Who Broke With Marcos, Dies at 94
item.description: Considered a ruthless Marcos henchman, he was later hailed as a national hero for breaking with the dictator, and went on to preside over an economic boom.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Robert Nickelsberg/Getty Images
item.media:description: Fidel V. Ramos in 1986, the year of a popular uprising in the Philippines that led to the ouster of the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos.

item.title: How the Kremlin Is Forcing Ukrainians to Adopt Russian Life
item.description: In Russian-occupied regions in Ukraine, local leaders are forcing civilians to accept Russian rule. Next come sham elections that would formalize Vladimir V. Putin’s claim that they are Russian territories.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Sergei Ilnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Palestinian Flags Aren’t Illegal in Israel. They Still Get Torn Down.
item.description: Israeli police, lawmakers and settlers are increasingly targeting the flag, which Palestinians say is a broader attack on their identity.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Ahmad Gharabli/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers scuffling with a woman trying to raise a Palestinian flag in Jerusalem in May.

item.title: Followers of Iraqi Cleric Occupy Parliament Again, Demanding Reforms
item.description: Unable to form a government 10 months after elections, Iraq has been roiled by the street protests of the nationalist cleric Moktada al-Sadr, who withdrew from the government but again seeks to influence it.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Ahmad Al-Rubaye/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of the Iraqi cleric Moqtada Sadr raised portraits of their leader inside the country’s parliament in the capital Baghdad’s high-security Green Zone, as they protest against a rival bloc’s nomination for prime minister, on Saturday.

item.title: In Widening Crackdown, Renowned Journalist Arrested in Guatemala
item.description: José Rubén Zamora, an award-winning journalist and president of the elPeriódico newspaper, was arrested at his home in Guatemala City.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Lopez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Johan Ordonez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: José Rubén Zamora, a prominent journalist, was arrested in Guatemala City on Friday.

item.title: Francis Calls Abuse of Indigenous People in Canada a ‘Genocide’
item.description: The pope reinforced his denunciation of the abuse committed by Roman Catholic-run schools in the country. He also acknowledged that his advancing age might force him to travel less in future.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Guglielmo Mangiapane
item.media:description: Francis held a news conference on Friday aboard the papal plane on his flight to Rome from Canada.

item.title: A Polish Priest’s War Against Abortion Focuses on Helping Single Mothers
item.description: The Rev. Tomasz Kancelarczyk sees little effect on women’s decisions whether to have a child from a 29-year abortion ban. What may matter more is support for women who choose to have a child.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Anna Liminowicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Father Kancelarczyk at Little Feet House, a shelter he runs for single mothers.

item.title: Gangs Advance on the Seat of Haitian Government Power: ‘Haitians Are Hostages’
item.description: Over 470 people have been killed, injured or are missing in recent violence, according to the U.N., as gangs expand their control and threaten the presidential palace.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Andre Paultre
item.media:credit: Ralph Tedy Erol/Reuters
item.media:description: Motorcycle drivers passing through a burning roadblock as anger mounted over fuel shortages that have intensified as a result of gang violence this month in Port-au-Prince.

item.title: Heavy Rain Causes Deadly Flooding Across Iran
item.description: The monsoon-like rains, unusual for the typical dry season in the region, have killed more than 50 people, caused heavy damage and shut down major roadways.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Fatemeh Bahrami/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene after flash flooding in Imamzadeh Davood, a suburb of Tehran, on Thursday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky urges mass evacuations.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of thousands of civilians living in eastern Ukraine were ordered to evacuate their homes this weekend.

item.title: Using Nuclear Reactors for Cover, Russians Lob Rockets at Ukrainians
item.description: Russia has turned Europe’s largest nuclear power plant into a fortress, stymying Ukraine’s forces and unnerving locals who fear both shelling and a radiation leak.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, across the Dnipro River from the Ukrainian town of Nikopol, is being used by occupying Russian forces to fire on Ukrainian towns and military positions.

item.title: Tensions Flare on Kosovo-Serbian Border Amid Protests and Gunfire
item.description: Demonstrations against a law related to new license plates for ethnic Serbs in Kosovo led to gunfire on Sunday, leading to concerns that the violence could escalate further.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: Putin’s Former Climate Czar is Hospitalized in Europe
item.description: Anatoly Chubais, who resigned and left Russia in March, had grown numb in his hands and legs.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Pool Photo by Associated Press
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin, left, and Anatoly Chubais meeting near Moscow in 2016. Mr. Chubais had been an ally of Mr. Putin’s since the 1990s.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Civilians in Donetsk Are Urged to Evacuate
item.description: Also, Nancy Pelosi heads to Singapore and global issues challenge Latin America’s rising left.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian evacuees boarded a train at the Pokrovks train station on Sunday. Hundreds of thousands of civilians living in eastern Ukraine were ordered to evacuate their homes this weekend after months of relentless Russian bombardment destroyed the infrastructure needed to deliver heat and electricity.

item.title: As Ukraine Orders Civilians to Evacuate the East, Residents Face a Grim Choice
item.description: The president’s announcement is the broadest government directive issued thus far in the war, coming after months of relentless Russian bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Erika Solomon
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: An evacuation train heading west from the Donetsk region on Sunday.

item.title: As India Bans Disposable Plastic, Tamil Nadu Offers Lessons
item.description: Tamil Nadu’s ban on single-use plastic has gotten results, thanks to relentless policing. Now, India says it will tackle the problem nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Anindito Mukherjee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amul Vasudevan, right, selling vegetables in July along a busy road in Chennai, India. “Plastic bags can only be eliminated if the customer decides it, not the seller,” she said.

item.title: Red Cross Still Blocked From Russian Prison Camp Where Ukranians Were Killed
item.description: The Russian Defense Ministry had said it would allow the United Nations and the Red Cross to visit the site.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Diana, center, whose father is among those at the Olenivka camp, at a gathering in Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, on Saturday for families of P.O.W.s.

item.title: In Libyan Town Searching for Justice, a Struggle Even to Find Graves
item.description: Libya’s political chaos has left little room for the reconciliation that many residents see as necessary for peace. Few places feel that more than Tarhuna, where a murderous band of brothers reigned for years.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kani brothers’ notorious detention center in the town of Tarhuna. The brothers found allies at different times on both sides of Libya’s political divide.

item.title: Oleksiy Vadaturskyi, one of Ukraine’s richest businessmen, is killed in Mykolaiv.
item.description: Oleksiy Vadaturskyi, whose company built storage facilities and infrastructure necessary for exporting grain, was killed with his wife in a missile strike.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A harbor used by the Nibulon company in the Mykolaiv region for the export of grain.

item.title: The Spread of Book Banning
item.description: Explaining the increasing politicization of the book banning debate.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Books at a New Jersey high school library that were targeted for bans.

item.title: Ukraine Calls for Investigation Into Prison Explosion
item.description: Ukrainian authorities gathered evidence that they said showed Russia had orchestrated an explosion that killed at least 50 of their soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Maria Varenikova and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Maliuchenko, 23, whose fiancé is among those at the Olenivka prison camp, at a gathering in Kyiv on Saturday where families of Ukrainian P.O.W.s demanded an investigation into an explosion that killed 50 prisoners.

item.title: Prisoners describe harsh treatment in the Russian camp where an explosion killed dozens.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova, Oleksandr Chubko and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A soldier outside the Olenivka prison on Friday after an explosion killed dozens of Ukrainian prisoners of war who were being held there.

item.title: Ukrainian officials compile evidence that they say shows Russia was behind prison camp blast.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A destroyed barrack at a prison in the town of Olenivka, in an area in eastern Ukraine controlled by Russia.

item.title: US Defense Department Official Says Russia’s War Effort Is Failing
item.description: A senior U.S. Defense Department official said there was growing evidence that steep Russian losses had left some units ill-prepared to fight.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank moved forward to fire toward Russian positions in the Kharkiv region of northeastern Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Podcast Recommendations
item.description: Try out a new podcast or two, courtesy of Morning readers.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Excitement, Then Ambivalence, For the Pope’s Visit to Quebec
item.description: Thousands gathered on Wednesday to see Pope Francis ride by the Plains of Abraham park. But a mass the following day was not a big draw.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Vincenzo Pinto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving at the National Shrine of Sainte-Anne-de-Beaupré in Quebec on Thursday.

item.title: A European official denounces ‘inhumane, barbaric acts’ as dozens of prisoners of war are killed.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Alexander Ermochenko/Reuters
item.media:description: The covered bodies on Friday of people killed when an explosion tore through the barracks of a prison camp in Russian-controlled territory in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Vessels await word that they can carry the first grain shipments out of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Navi-Star cargo ship docked beside grain silos at the Port of Odesa on Friday.

item.title: Breaking Agreement to Use a Condom Is a Sex Crime, Canada High Court Rules
item.description: The Supreme Court ruling is one of the strictest in a recent spate of measures addressing deceptive condom use, as courts try to define consent.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Blair Gable/Reuters
item.media:description: Canada’s Supreme Court has ruled that removing a condom during sexual intercourse without getting explicit permission is a crime.

item.title: Blinken and Lavrov Discuss Griner in Their First Call of the War
item.description: Ukraine said it was ready for Black Sea grain shipments to resume, while the top Russian and American diplomats talked about a prisoner swap involving the basketball star Brittney Griner.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Michael Crowley and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Russian Foreign Ministry, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Russian government showing Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov during a news conference on Friday in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.

item.title: Explosion Kills Dozens of Ukrainian Captives at Russian-Held Prison
item.description: At least 50 captured fighters died in a blast at a prison in eastern Ukraine, with no clarity on exactly what happened and each country blaming the other.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Valerie Hopkins and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A soldier at the prison on Friday.

item.title: A Ukrainian appeals court reduces the life sentence of a Russian soldier tried for war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Vladyslav Musiienko/Reuters
item.media:description: Vadim Shishimarin during an appeal court hearing on Monday. He was sentenced to life in prison in May after pleading guilty to shooting a 62-year-old man on a bicycle.

item.title: Three Pressing Questions About Monkeypox: Spread, Vaccination, Treatment
item.description: Containing the outbreak, scientists say, will depend on better understanding the virus’s transmission and how well available tools work.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Eduardo Munoz/Reuters
item.media:description: A man receives a monkeypox vaccination at the Northwell Health Immediate Care Center at Fire Island-Cherry Grove, in New York.

item.title: Lethal missile strikes in Kharkiv hit sites related to Ukraine’s military, a new pattern.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Pressure Grows for U.A.E. to Free Asim Ghafoor, American Lawyer
item.description: Asim Ghafoor once represented the Saudi dissident and columnist Jamal Khashoggi, who was murdered in 2018 by Saudi agents. He was arrested this month in Dubai.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/ The New York Times
item.media:description: Asim Ghafoor, left, in Washington in 2008. American consular officials have been unable to reach him in recent days.

item.title: Blinken and Lavrov Discuss Prisoner Swap Involving Griner and Whelan
item.description: Antony Blinken, the secretary of state, declined to say how his Russian counterpart responded as he continued to seek the release of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan, a former Marine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he spoke with Sergey V. Lavrov, his Russian counterpart, on Friday. It was their first call since Russia invaded Ukraine in February.

item.title: Lebanon Weighs Ukraine Claim That Syrian Ship Holds Stolen Grain
item.description: The Laodicea, a Syrian cargo ship, arrived in Tripoli, Lebanon, on Wednesday carrying nearly 10 tons of wheat and barley.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Yoruk Isik/Reuters

item.title: Lavrov To Propose a Time to Discuss Possible Prisoner Swap for Brittney Griner
item.description: Sergey Lavrov said he would listen to what U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken had to say about a proposal for the release of Brittney Griner and another American.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Russian Foreign Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister, at a news conference in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, on Friday.

item.title: Why Pelosi’s Proposed Taiwan Visit Is Raising U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: Beijing has issued strongly worded warnings implying that China might use military force if Nancy Pelosi moves forward with a planned trip to Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Jane Perlez
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi at the Capitol in January.

item.title: The Big Economic Question
item.description: It is not whether the U.S. is in a recession. It’s whether the economy will soon worsen.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Verónica G. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Villanueva family at a market in Alamo, Texas.

item.title: Deaths of Two Saudi Sisters in Australia Mystifies Police
item.description: Their bodies lay undiscovered for a month. Weeks later, the police still know little about the women or what happened to them.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Why Catholicism Remains Strong in Canada
item.description: Even as Catholicism wanes in many Western countries, in Canada, it is holding steady as the largest religious denomination.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Angela Sanil, left, her sister Ashlyn, their mother Cinol and their friend Babitha Abraham came to see Pope Francis at Commonwealth Stadium, in Edmonton, Alberta. Cinol and her husband Jacob immigrated to Canada from South India in 2010. An influx of Catholic immigrants has helped the Canadian Catholic Church build up new membership.

item.title: Dr. Oh Eun-young of ‘My Golden Kids’ Puts Therapy on TV
item.description: In South Korea, Dr. Oh Eun-young, a celebrated psychiatrist, has helped destigmatize seeking therapy and blown up the traditionally private relationship with patients by putting it all on TV.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Oh Eun-young, a specialist in child and adolescent psychiatry, is called a national hero by many South Koreans for destigmatizing language around mental health and seeking therapy.

item.title: I’ll Trade You Some Cursed Baby Dolls and Metal Frogs for That Unwanted Banana Statue
item.description: John Oliver is willing to make a deal for a piece of (formerly) public art in Fitzroy. That doesn’t mean negotiations have been easy.
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: The neighborhood of Fitzroy in Melbourne, Australia. It’s quite hip.

item.title: Facing Gas Shortages, Europe Seeks to Shrink Demand for Energy
item.description: Germany may be most vulnerable to Russia’s energy squeeze, but many other countries are also facing, at minimum, high prices and restricted supples.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina, Dan Bilefsky, Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A power plant run by CEZ Group in Chorzow, Poland, in February.

item.title: Hong Kong: Mirror Concert Accident to Be Investigated
item.description: Two dancers for the popular boy band were hospitalized, a local news outlet reported. Hong Kong officials promised an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: via Associated Press
item.media:description: Video on social media showed a video screen falling during Mirror’s performance at the Hong Kong Coliseum on Thursday night.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A potential U.S. climate bill.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The legislation’s most immediate effect will be supercharging the growth of wind and other clean energy industries.

item.title: Germans Tiptoe Up the Path to Energy Savings
item.description: Local leaders find themselves at the front line of Europe’s conservation efforts, fearing a Russian gas cut. It’s not an easy place to be.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: People playing in an outdoor pool in Augsburg, Germany. The city has lowered the temperature of outdoor public pools by one degree to save energy.

item.title: Why the U.S. Offered to Swap Griner for Bout, a Russian Arms Dealer
item.description: The negotiations raise questions about what, if any, standards should apply when the United States agrees to trade prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press
item.media:description: Some observers say a proposed prisoner swap of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner, right, for the arms dealer Viktor Bout would only encourage hostage taking.

item.title: There are no immediate signs of a speedy Brittney Griner deal in either Moscow or Washington.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexander Zemlianichenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner in a Russian court on Wednesday. She has been detained in Russia since her arrest at an airport in February.

item.title: England Overhauls Medical Care for Transgender Youth
item.description: The National Health Service is closing England’s sole youth gender clinic, which had been criticized for long wait times and inadequate services.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi
item.media:credit: Jeffrey Blackler/Alamy
item.media:description: The Tavistock Gender Identity Development Service in London had more than 5,000 patient referrals from 2021 to 2022.

item.title: Russia’s media regulator moves to revoke the license of Novaya Gazeta, an independent news outlet.
item.dc:creator: James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Dimitar Dilkoff/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Novaya Gazeta’s Moscow office in October. Its editor, Dmitri A. Muratov, won the Nobel Peace Prize last year.

item.title: Why a Vogue Cover Created a Controversy for Olena Zelenska
item.description: Is the magazine romanticizing war, or is the first lady weaponizing glossies?
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: Climate Change Worsened Britain’s Heat Wave, Scientists Find
item.description: Scorchers like the one last week are still unusual, but global warming is making them more likely, and worse when they do strike.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Danny Lawson/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A waterway from the Dowry Reservoir near Oldham, England, was reduced to a trickle.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden and Xi’s Fraught Phone Call
item.description: Also, U.S. G.D.P. declined again and an Australian law against foreign meddling will be tested.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik and Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Wednesday.

item.title: In Kharkiv, powerful missiles hit central areas and plans for the future.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian missiles struck a mechanic’s shop in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday morning, leaving debris and a tangled web of metal in its wake.

item.title: Russians, Risking Isolation in the South, Build Up for Ukrainian Attack
item.description: Russia is moving “maximum” forces to the south, which presents a role reversal from the eastern Donbas region: Ukraine is on the offensive and Russians holding a key city risk being cut off.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Maria Varenikova and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers cleaning up in front of a building hit by rockets on Thursday in Kharkiv, Ukraine.
